custom.usage:
import { App } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";
const { App } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import App
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;

docs.remarks:
Apps can be as big or small as you like - from a single webserver to dozens of load-balanced instances serving different parts of your application.

This example illustrates how to run a simple app that contains a webservice created from a Dockerfile. We make a new App instance, then we add a WebService to the production stack:

import { App, WebService } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";

const app = new App();

new WebService(app.production, "prod-web", {
  dockerfile: "../Dockerfile"
});
const { App, WebService } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");

const app = new App();

new WebService(app.production, "prod-web", {
  dockerfile: "../Dockerfile"
});
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import App, WebService

app = App()

WebService(app.production, "prod-web",
    dockerfile="../Dockerfile"
)
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;

App app = new App();

new WebService(app.Production, "prod-web", new WebServiceProps {
    Dockerfile = "../Dockerfile"
});
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebService;

App app = new App();

WebService.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "prod-web")
        .dockerfile("../Dockerfile")
        .build();
docs.summary: App serves as an entry point to your CloudCamp application. It's typically instantiated in the beginning of your program and sets up your application's configuration and build pipeline. An App instance contains one or more Stacks, which you can use to add your own resources, for example a WebService or a Database.

custom.remarks: To create a CloudCamp application, instantiate an App object. App is a singleton - i.e. there can only be a single instance at a time.
custom.signature: new App()new App()new App()new App()new App()
static instance: Appstatic instancestatic instance: Appstatic App Instancestatic App getInstance()

custom.remarks:
To deploy resources to the cloud, they are added to a Stack. Stacks come in handy to isolate different environments from each other. For example, you might have a stack for testing your application and another one for the production version.

CloudCamp comes with three default stacks:
custom.signature: network: Stacknetworknetwork: StackStack NetworkStack getNetwork()

docs.summary: Use this stack for anything related to the network, for example to set up DNS entries.

custom.signature: pipeline: CodePipelinepipelinepipeline: CodePipelineCodePipeline PipelineCodePipeline getPipeline()
production: Stackproductionproduction: StackStack ProductionStack getProduction()
staging: Stackstagingstaging: StackStack StagingStack getStaging()

docs.summary: Use this stack to create an environment for testing changes before deploying to production.

docs.summary: The order in which stages are executed. For example, to ensure the custom stage "development" is always executed before production:

custom.remarks: In addition to the default stacks provided by CloudCamp, you can create your own stacks.
custom.signature: stack(name: string): Stackstack(name)stack(name: str) -> StackStack Stack(name: String)Stack stack(String name)

docs.remarks:
Pass a stack name to create a new, empty stack. If the stack does not exist already, a new one will be created.

const devStack = app.stack("development");
const devStack = app.stack("development");
dev_stack = app.stack("development")
Stack devStack = app.Stack("development");
Stack devStack = app.stack("development");
docs.summary: Add a new stack or access an existing one.

custom.remarks: Stages are responsible for building your stacks. By default, CloudCamp creates a stage for each stack and gives it the same name. You can customize this behaviour by adding your own stages.
custom.signature: stage(name: string, stage?: Stage): Stagestage(name, stage)stage(name: str, stage: Stage) -> StageStage Stage(name: String, stage?: Stage)Stage stage(String name, Stage stage)

docs.remarks:
Stages can be obtained by their name to modify their attributes. A common use case is to require manual approval to deploy to the production stage:

const stage = app.getStage("production");
stage.needsManualApproval = true;
const stage = app.getStage("production");
stage.needsManualApproval = true;
stage = app.get_stage("production")
stage.needs_manual_approval = True
var stage = app.GetStage("production");
stage.NeedsManualApproval = true;
Object stage = app.getStage("production");
stage.setNeedsManualApproval(true);

You can also add a stage with a custom Stack subclass:

import { App, WebService, Stack } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";

class CustomStack extends Stack {
   constructor(scope: cdk.Construct, id: string, props: cdk.StackProps) {
      super(scope, id, props);
      new WebService(this, "web", {
        dockerfile: "../Dockerfile"
      });
   }
}

// later in the code...
const app = new App();
const stage = app.stage("dev");
const stack = new CustomStack(stage, "dev");

// stack is automatically set to the new stack we created
if (stage.stack == stack) {
   // outputs "True!"
   console.log("True!");
}
const { App, WebService, Stack } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");

class CustomStack extends Stack {
   constructor(scope: cdk.Construct, id: string, props: cdk.StackProps) {
      super(scope, id, props);
      new WebService(this, "web", {
        dockerfile: "../Dockerfile"
      });
   }
}

// later in the code...
const app = new App();
const stage = app.stage("dev");
const stack = new CustomStack(stage, "dev");

// stack is automatically set to the new stack we created
if (stage.stack == stack) {
   // outputs "True!"
   console.log("True!");
}
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import App, WebService, Stack

class CustomStack(Stack):
    def __init__(self, scope, id, props):
        super().__init__(scope, id, props)
        WebService(self, "web",
            dockerfile="../Dockerfile"
        )

# later in the code...
app = App()
stage = app.stage("dev")
stack = CustomStack(stage, "dev")

# stack is automatically set to the new stack we created
if stage.stack == stack:
    # outputs "True!"
    print("True!")
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;

class CustomStack : Stack
{
    public CustomStack(cdk.Construct scope, string id, cdk.StackProps props) : base(scope, id, props)
    {
        new WebService(this, "web", new WebServiceProps {
            Dockerfile = "../Dockerfile"
        });
    }
}

// later in the code...
App app = new App();
Stage stage = app.Stage("dev");
CustomStack stack = new CustomStack(stage, "dev");

// stack is automatically set to the new stack we created
if (stage.Stack == stack)
{
    // outputs "True!"
    Console.WriteLine("True!");
}
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebService;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.Stack;

public class CustomStack extends Stack {
    public CustomStack(Construct scope, String id, StackProps props) {
        super(scope, id, props);
        WebService.Builder.create(this, "web")
                .dockerfile("../Dockerfile")
                .build();
    }
}

// later in the code...
App app = new App();
Stage stage = app.stage("dev");
CustomStack stack = new CustomStack(stage, "dev");

// stack is automatically set to the new stack we created
if (stage.getStack() == stack) {
    // outputs "True!"
    System.out.println("True!");
}
